summary: This is the last will and testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, dated August 8, 2019. It designates executors, outlines the payment of estate expenses, and bequeaths all of his property to the trustees of The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2018 Trust. The document details extensive powers granted to the executors for managing the estate. This is the last will and testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, executed on May 8, 2018. It details the disposition of his estate, including provisions for taxes, the creation of a trust, and clauses disinheriting any beneficiary who contests the will. The document includes witness signatures and a notary public's acknowledgment.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The individual creating the will, declaring himself a resident of St. Thomas, US Virgin Islands, and directing the distribution of his entire estate to a trust.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.context: Appointed as one of the primary executors of Epstein's will, responsible for administering the estate.

persons.name: Richard D. Kahn
persons.context: Appointed as one of the primary executors of Epstein's will, responsible for administering the estate alongside Darren K. Indyke.

persons.name: Kathryn H. Ruemmler
persons.context: Named as the successor executor if either Darren K. Indyke or Richard D. Kahn is unable or unwilling to serve.

persons.name: Habibe Avdiu
persons.context: The notary public who witnessed the signing and swearing of the will in New York County, New York.

connections.description: Epstein appointed Indyke as an executor of his will, granting him fiduciary authority over the estate.
Epstein appointed Kahn as an executor of his will, granting him fiduciary authority over the estate.
Epstein named Ruemmler as the successor executor in his will, indicating a trusted legal relationship.
Both are appointed as co-executors of Epstein's will, requiring them to act unanimously on certain decisions.

events.title: Execution of Epstein's Will
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein signed his last will and testament, designating executors and directing his estate to a trust.

events.title: Creation of The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2018 Trust
events.description: The trust agreement for The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2018 Trust was established, which is the beneficiary of Epstein's entire estate under the will.

events.title: Execution of Jeffrey Epstein's Will
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein signed his last will and testament in the presence of witnesses and a notary public.

locations: St. Thomas, United States Virgin Islands
Richmond County (where the notary public is qualified)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein declared himself a resident and domiciliary of St. Thomas, US Virgin Islands, at the time of making his will.
Epstein's entire estate, after expenses, is bequeathed to the trustees of 'The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2018 Trust', created on May 8, 2018.
Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn are appointed as the primary executors, each to receive $250,000 upon completion of probate.
Kathryn H. Ruemmler is named as the successor executor if Indyke or Kahn cannot serve.
The will grants executors extremely broad powers to manage, invest, sell, and litigate on behalf of the estate without needing judicial approval.
Jeffrey Epstein's last will and testament was executed on May 8, 2018, approximately 15 months before his death.
The will establishes a trust (referenced as 'the Trust Agreement') and directs the bulk of his estate to be distributed to the trustee(s) of that trust.
It contains a 'no-contest' clause, stating that any beneficiary who challenges the will or trust shall be disinherited.
The document details complex provisions for the apportionment and payment of federal and state estate taxes.
The will was notarized by Habibe Avdiu, a Notary Public for the State of New York.
